Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2013 01:45AM cdavisnyc wrote: Ballet, I bet you are correct. Plus, the guy who called is a new employee. I watched him being trained one day while I was parked in the waiting room. I hope they don't let the new guy deliver that kind of news! My sense of logic was malfunctioning that day, I think. It's been an emotional roller coaster, as I am sure you understand. You will have a smooth easy and fast biopsy on Monday. I will be thinking of you. -Colleen
Posts.Title: Biopsy today, help me analyze contributing factors? cdavisnyc SpecialK

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2013 08:39AM cdavisnyc wrote: Melissa, you know I am anything but usual!  SpecialK, thank you for this info. I hadn't thought to check insurance coverage. Everything has been covered so far, so it hasn't occurred to me. Thanks for pointing that out. Seems so obvious in hindsight, yet I missed it. Thank you again.  I do have reasons for wanting the Oncotype score. My mother did chemo first, to shrink the tumor before surgery. But the pathology report showed only a 30% reduction in size (and a Ki67 score of 66% WTF). If she had the predictive info first, she may have made different decisions, or perhaps she may have had different expectations. Right now she feels angry and betrayed and depressed. She had to go back for lumpectomy re-do because of postive margins. She read her pathology report and zoned in on "moderate response to treatment."  Moderate tells us not much at all. But she is very upset because she misunderstands. She sufffers from a lack of knowledge. I have decided that I will not.  For me personally, I love having as much data as possible. Why not do the genome typing on the biopsy sample? Why wait for surgery? Like you said, it gives you time to get your head around it. Make a plan. Prepare. And if your tumor doesn't react well to chemo, there's no reason to do it. And there is no reason to go through 4 dose-dense A/C treatments and THEN re-scan for response (yes, that was mom again). She was told the tumor was gone! They would perform a "ghostectomy" instead of lumpectomy. After I read the pathology report, that was simply untrue. I think the odds are in my favor, but I am preparing for the next step if the biopsy comes back positive. I have been watching my mother so closely that I can't help but imagine myself in the same situation. And she may very well have gone through all that suffering for nothing. Just because her tumor wasn't genome-typed. And we didn't know enough to ask. And we still don't have that information. And that's partially my fault. She starts radiation in three weeks.  Everyone's journey is different. But her journey informs mine simply because I have a front row seat. And, I am still trying to help her on her journey. Which is a WHOLE OTHER POST. And it will involve lots of wine. And whine. And then some more wine. Thank you so much for your input. It helps me a lot! Keep it coming.  -Colleen
Posts.Title: Biopsy today, help me analyze contributing factors? cdavisnyc SpecialK

Posts.Content: cdavisnyc wrote: This is what I think, and please feel free to comment: -My mother has breast cancer (fast-growing, KI-67 proliferation rate 66%), BRCA negative, which means that my chance of having cancer genetically passed to me is low, but the odds increase anyway, just because she has it. That's no help at all. - I am 43 years old, pre-menopausal, with dense breasts, so given my mother's condition, mammograms and ultrasounds are almost guaranteed to lead me to a biopsy and nothing but a biopsy will give me actual useful data. -my mass is between 1.5cm-2cm, lobular, with defined edges, but they can't see into it. I can't really feel it. I have large breasts, and no symptoms. The way I figure it, I start with a 20% statistical average of my biopsy coming back positive for cancer. Then, that number gets jacked up due to my mother's status, then back down due to my age and dense breast tissue, and I think I'm back where I started.  Can anyone give me a better insight? At least until I get the biopsy report on Monday or Tuesday? I'm trying to stay objective and I love data. Oh, and if I have cancer, what should I be sure to do now with the biopsy sample to get the genome typing? Oncotype vs. Mammoprint?  Where am I right, and is there a point where I am completely off-base? Thanks for any help you can offer, -Colleen. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Biopsy today, help me analyze contributing factors? cdavisnyc SpecialK

Grrrrr.  I'll report back when I get my results.  Also, these steri-strips ITCH. I want to pull them off but I am resisting the urge. My boyfriend says that my breast now has a "ski-jump." I hope that amuses you all as much as it amused me. -Colleen
Posts.Title: Biopsy today, help me analyze contributing factors? cdavisnyc SpecialK

Posts.Content: May 31, 2013 08:29PM cdavisnyc wrote: Hi Melissa and Peggy, I'm actually doing very well. Not too anxious at all. It's funny. I flip out when I'm looking at a needle, but waiting for results just makes me feel annoyed. Rest assured, I am passing the time with activities other than obsessively researching breast cancer.  Today is treadmill day (but with a fresh biopsy site, I'm just walking. No running!) I have work tonight, then a weekend of cooking and reading a good book and maybe Minecraft. That game is a time-suck. I refuse to do housework this weekend. Nope. Not gonna.  I've been with my mother through her treatment for breast cancer (she is having her lumpectomy re-do today -positive margins, gah), so I already know A LOT about chemo and surgery and Oncotype/Mammaprint scores and reading pathology reports. In three weeks, I will know a lot about radiation treatments too. I think 20% is as accurate as I can get right now. Darn dense breasts. I'm assuming I don't have cancer, but if I do, I know from experience how important it is to have all the information you can get.  My mother did chemo first, surgery second. If I have to start making decisions, I would want that Oncotype info first, before any treatment starts. I know they usually do it after surgery, but I would imagine it could be typed from the biopsy sample. I'll find out. Thanks for your input and info! -Colleen
Posts.Title: Biopsy today, help me analyze contributing factors? cdavisnyc SpecialK

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2013 06:33AM cdavisnyc wrote: For anyone who is considering it as well, it appears that you can get an Oncotype DX from a core biopsy sample! From their website: "The Oncotype DX test is performed on a small amount of the tissue removed during your original surgery (lumpectomy, mastectomy or core biopsy). This means you should not have to undergo any additional invasive procedures for the test to be performed." Also, info on eligibility for this test: "If you are a woman with newly diagnosed Lymph Node Negative (N-), oestrogen receptor positive (ER+), and Stage I-II invasive breast cancer (also known as primary breast cancer), you may be eligible for the test. Also, Post-menopausal women with ER+ Lymph Node Positive disease (up to 3 nodes positive), may also be appropriate candidates."

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2013 10:01PM cdavisnyc wrote: You're right about that. It is only useful with certain types of tumors. In my mother's case, it would have been very useful to have because she did chemo first without have a predictor of how effective the chemo would be, and now she is second-guessing whether the chemo was worth it. I hate seeing her so distressed. You're also right about not putting the cart before the horse! I'm just..... let's say checking out all the carts in case I need to hitch my horse to one. To keep the metaphor going, I think my mother's doctor pointed at a cart and she took it without asking any questions, and now regrets it. I want a better cart than that one. Thanks for your advice, I appreciate it very much! Good luck right back at you.

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2013 08:52PM cdavisnyc wrote: SpecialK and Juliaanna, A very special thank you for speaking with me so intelligently. The "have a cup of tea and try not worry about it" kind of advice doesn't work for me. It's not bad advice at all! It just doesn't work for me. I would have to research the best kind of tea to drink first. lol. I don't disagree with anything either of you have said. And I will re-read it a few times whenever I need a reminder. The info you provided on typing a biopsy sample is especially helpful. I didn't understand why it wasn't more commonly done, and you have answered that question so very well. Also, compartmentalizing is excellent advice. I needed to hear that. I'm usually very good at that, but for some reason, I lose that ability when I'm dealing with Mom. As for Mom, she heard her surgeon say that his goal was "complete pathological response" and hung on to that. I knew it was unlikely and I wasn't surprised. I was a little surprised at the positive margins, but mostly because I felt her frustration. I know there are always surprises in the journey, and every journey is different. I just get so frustrated watching her, and I can't help. I try to get her in a positive mindset, and also prepare her for things like that, but she doesn't listen to me much. There's that frustration again. Mothers. What can you do? To conclude, if my biopsy comes back positive, then please join me on the next discussion board! And even if it comes back negative, I suspect there will be more biopsies in my future. This discussion has helped me greatly to keep it all in perspective. I am grateful for that. I will post my results, hopefully tomorrow! Thank you all so very much. You have my admiration and respect. I don't want to join your club, but if I ever do, I will be in excellent company. -Colleen

It's irritating and distracting. But if that's my worst complaint, life is pretty good. Molinda, please let us know when your biopsy is and what your experience is. I want to know!

Posts.Title: Has anyone brought a friend/SO/medical advocate to a biopsy? cdavisnyc cdavisnyc

Posts.Content: May 30, 2013 08:43PM cdavisnyc wrote: Update: I had the biopsy today. I decided to go it alone. My original plan was to be terrified. But, I did a couple of things to keep my anxiety under control, and the revised plan went very well: -I scheduled it on a busy day for me, instead of my day off. Distractions are good for me.  -My best friend stayed with me most of the day, keeping me occupied and getting me to & from my appointment. She kept notes of the questions I wanted to ask and made sure that I got the answers.  -My therapist gave me a handful of clay to play with, kind of like a stress ball. I gave that thing a workout. -Breathing. I forget to breathe when I get anxious. Deep breaths - in through the nose, out through the mouth. Visualize whatever makes you feel good and strong. -I listened to music on my ipod in one ear (instrumental, soothing, beautiful, low volume). -I asked lots of questions, and kept up a conversation with my Dr. and ultrasound tech. They are very interesting people. -oh, and Xanax. After one of those, I change from being speechless to being able to have a conversation. I am happy to report that it didn't hurt at all (I always think they are lying when they say it won't hurt), and it went very quickly. I feel proud of myself that I managed the anxiety. I went right back to work. I've been taking Tylenol, but it's been 9 hours now, and I don't feel any pain at the biopsy site. I think the biggest pain is going to be peeling the medical tape off. That, and I'm restricted to sponge baths for a few days while it's HOT in NYC.  I hope this helps anyone who is anticipating their appointment. I think I'll zip over to the Waiting for Results forum. I have a weekend to kill. Keep breathing, everyone. -Colleen
Posts.Title: Has anyone brought a friend/SO/medical advocate to a biopsy? cdavisnyc cdavisnyc

Posts.Content: May 31, 2013 07:22AM cdavisnyc wrote: Hi Molinda,  I would be happy to tell you my list. Good plan on bringing your BFF. Mine was a rockstar. She kept notes for me and reminded me to breathe. I keep forgetting to breathe. 1. I told them I have an issue with needles and to please keep them out of my sightline. (yeah, too late, I saw them anyway) 2. I told them my fear response is crying. I'm not getting emotional or hysterical or anything (people think that automatically). It's just my fear response, and they should ignore it.  #2 turned out not to be necessary because, for the first time EVER, I managed that fear response successfully. Big pat on the back for me! 3. I asked them to tell me everything they were doing. Staying occupied helps me. They talked me through it and even showed me the sound the machine makes before taking the first sample. 4. How many samples are you taking? (They took 3) 5. My mother got a titanium marker placed at the biopsy site. Are you planning to give me one? (She said she wasn't planning on it, but if I wanted one I could have one! We laughed and I said no thanks.) 6. When will the results be ready and how can I find out what they are? (about 2 business days, and I can contact my Gyno, who ordered the test.) 7. And back at the reception desk, we made sure to get copies of my previous tests (one mammogram, and then a focused compression mammogram and then ultrasound). My BFF hung on to those and didn't let me look at them until I was relaxed and ready to read them. Then, we went out to lunch. My treat, of course.  I had other questions about how to take care of the biopsy site afterwards, but they gave me a sheet of instructions with all that info. You will do great! Be sure to treat yourself well.  -Colleen
Posts.Title: Has anyone brought a friend/SO/medical advocate to a biopsy? cdavisnyc cdavisnyc

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2013 08:17PM cdavisnyc wrote: This is what I told my mother when she was diagnosed: Keep breathing. Deep breaths. Take notes. Make lists of questions. When you are ready, pop over to the "Just Diagnosed" section of the boards.
